dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey B, you know, there's been some pretty big news from Pfizer this week, uh, that I think we need to talk about.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey B, you know, there's been some pretty big news from Pfizer this week, uh, that I think we need to talk about.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah? What's up with Pfizer? I thought they were, like, really far along with their vaccine?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah? What's up with Pfizer? I thought they were, like, really far along with their vaccine?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bourlas statement cements Pfizers status as a frontrunner alongside Germanys BioNTech, who it is developing the vaccine with in the global race to develop a safe and effective Covid-19 vaccine.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, they are, but they just announced they're actually going to delay their application for emergency approval for their COVID-19 vaccine.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, they are, but they just announced they're actually going to delay their application for emergency approval for their C O V I D-nineteen vaccine.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pfizer will apply to the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for emergency approval of its Covid-19 vaccine in the third week of November, its CEO said Friday, assuming it receives positive results from its ongoing trial

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Oh, really? Wow. So, does that mean, like, no vaccine before the election then? Because I know, um, President Trump has been really pushing that narrative.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, really? Wow. So, does that mean, like, no vaccine before the election then? Because I know, um, President Trump has been really pushing that narrative.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pfizer and other vaccine-makers have grown increasingly frustrated with the persistent politicization of potential Covid-19 vaccines by high-ranking officials, most notably President Trump, who has claimed one will be ready before the November 3 election.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's exactly it. I mean, the CEO, Albert Bourla, he basically confirmed that, like, a pre-election vaccine is pretty much off the table now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's exactly it. I mean, the C E O, Albert Bourla, he basically confirmed that, like, a pre-election vaccine is pretty much off the table now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: the timeline makes it unlikely that the U.S. will have a vaccine before the election but leaves open the possibility of one being authorized this year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Hmm. So, what's the holdup, A? What are they saying is the reason for the delay?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hmm. So, what's the holdup, A? What are they saying is the reason for the delay?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, uh, Bourla explained it. He said the FDA, the Food and Drug Administration, they require at least two months of safety data on half of the trial participants.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, uh, Bourla explained it. He said the F D A, the Food and Drug Administration, they require at least two months of safety data on half of the trial participants.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The FDA requires at least two months of safety data on half of trial participants to grant emergency approval, he said, as well as information on effectiveness and proof it can be manufactured safely.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, safety first, obviously. [overlaps] But didn't they, like, already have a lot of that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, safety first, obviously. But didn't they, like, already have a lot of that?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but he said they need that *specific* two months of data *after* the last dose. And also, you know, proof it can be manufactured safely and all that effectiveness data.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but he said they need that specific two months of data after the last dose. And also, you know, proof it can be manufactured safely and all that effectiveness data.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The FDA requires at least two months of safety data on half of trial participants to grant emergency approval, he said, as well as information on effectiveness and proof it can be manufactured safely.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so it's not just about, like, whether it works, but also the long-term safety and, uh, how they're gonna mass-produce it. That makes sense, I guess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so it's not just about, like, whether it works, but also the long-term safety and, uh, how they're gonna mass-produce it. That makes sense, I guess.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. He did say the safety data is probably the quickest to collect, but then they need manufacturing data, and they should know if it's ineffective by the end of October.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. He did say the safety data is probably the quickest to collect, but then they need manufacturing data, and they should know if it's ineffective by the end of October.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The safety data is likely to take the longest to collect Bourla said Pfizer expects to have manufacturing data before that and should know whether or not the vaccine is effective by the end of October.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: End of October... So, it's still possible this year, though, right? Like, after the election?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: End of October... So, it's still possible this year, though, right? Like, after the election?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: the timeline makes it unlikely that the U.S. will have a vaccine before the election but leaves open the possibility of one being authorized this year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, totally. The door's still open for authorization by the end of the year. But, uh, Bourla was pretty clear that they're not rushing things for political timelines.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, totally. The door's still open for authorization by the end of the year. But, uh, Bourla was pretty clear that they're not rushing things for political timelines.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: leaves open the possibility of one being authorized this year...Bourlas letter does little to hide this annoyance,stating: To ensure public trust and clear up a great deal of confusion, I believe it is essential for the public to understand our estimated timelines for each of these three areas.

dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] Which is good, honestly. I mean, you don't want a rushed vaccine.

dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, he really emphasized that Pfizer and other vaccine makers are, uh, increasingly *concerned* about the politicization of the vaccine. You know, with officials pushing for a pre-election timeline.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, he really emphasized that Pfizer and other vaccine makers are, uh, increasingly concerned about the politicization of the vaccine. You know, with officials pushing for a pre-election timeline.

dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. So, sticking to the science, uh, even if it means a delay.
